awd_titl_txt: EAGER: MAKER:  Student Learning Trajectories from Making Activities
awd_abstract_narration:
Arizona State University seeks to understand how open-ended, hands-on Making work and activities can reflect student learning gains in formal engineering education, particularly in an undergraduate, product-based course. The aim is to expand understanding of what Making and learning through Making in the context of engineering design education might be.  The results generated during this study will describe the learning trajectories of engineers as they learn Making. These results will illustrate educational pathways within the engineering education curriculum that could be further studied. By examining the engineering student Making learning experience this work can impact the quality of engineering design teaching.

The intellectual merit of this project will be the advancement of knowledge of the learning pathways of Making through capturing empirical evidence in the engineering classroom using multiple qualitative methods.  This exploratory project will address the relationship of a Making mindset and engineering design practice.  The results will have the potential to highlight routes to Making learning that can illustrate pathways to engineering as well as a means for faculty and institutions to adopt a Making mindset approach in engineering design learning that is more inclusive.

This project is a part of NSF's Maker Dear Colleague Letter (DCL) portfolio (NSF 15-086), a collaborative investment of Directorates for Computer & Information Science & Engineering (CISE), Education and Human Resources (EHR) and Engineering (ENG).

Accomplishments

The primary objective of this research project was to explore the impact of hands-on making activities on the learning trajectories of engineering students, particularly within product-based learning environments. Our goal was to enhance understanding of how making contributes to engineering education and to identify pathways that improve learning experiences in engineering curricula.

 

Major Goals and Activities

Our research was centered around two key questions: 1) How do engineering students learn and apply making? 2) What are the attributes of making in the engineering classroom? To address these questions, we conducted semi-structured interviews with faculty and students, gaining insights into course structures and pedagogical approaches related to making.

We gathered valuable perspectives on how creative opportunities are integrated within and beyond the engineering curriculum. Additionally, we examined the role of fundamental engineering principles in supporting learning and the significance of making and prototyping in extracurricular activities and student competitions.

 

Significant Results

Our findings underscore the importance of balancing technical knowledge with design practice within engineering curricula. Engineering science courses provide essential technical content, while design experiences—such as cornerstone and capstone projects—offer context for applying problem-solving skills. Moreover, extracurricular activities, including ad-hoc making projects and student competitions, enrich formal learning by providing practical, hands-on experiences.

A notable outcome of this project was the redesign of local design courses to emphasize iterative processes, reflection, and prototyping. These modifications aim to better incorporate making into the engineering curriculum, thereby enhancing student engagement and learning outcomes.

 

Training and Professional Development

The project offered significant training opportunities for three undergraduate researchers. They gained experience in qualitative research methods, including conducting interviews and analyzing data. This experience has contributed to their professional development and deepened their understanding of engineering education research.

 

Dissemination of Results

Our findings have been shared with the academic community through presentations at the American Society of Engineering Education (ASEE) annual conference. Additionally, the undergraduate researchers presented their work at a local undergraduate research symposium, further promoting engagement with our research.

 

Intellectual Merit

This project advances the field of engineering education by providing new insights into how hands-on making activities influence learning trajectories. By exploring the integration of making into engineering curricula, our research contributes to a deeper understanding of how practical experiences shape students' problem-solving skills and design thinking. The redesign of design courses to incorporate iterative processes and prototyping offers a novel approach to enhancing engineering education, potentially influencing curriculum development practices at other institutions. Our findings also provide a framework for assessing the impact of making on student learning, which can be used to refine educational strategies and improve the effectiveness of engineering design teaching.

 

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts of this project extend beyond engineering education to influence various aspects of STEM learning and professional development. By highlighting the importance of making and hands-on activities in learning trajectories, our research promotes a more inclusive and engaging approach to education. This work can be applied to other disciplines, providing a framework for understanding and improving learning processes across fields. Additionally, the project contributes to the development of future engineers and educators by enhancing design education and fostering interdisciplinary collaboration. The insights gained can also inform policy and practice in educational institutions, supporting the integration of practical, project-based learning into curricula. Furthermore, by involving undergraduate researchers and disseminating findings through conferences and symposia, the project supports the professional growth of emerging scholars and practitioners in the field.
